Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Creating Versatile Vibrotactile Displays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many consumer devices include vibrotactile technology to enhance the avenues of communication available to the user. Despite high expectations, this technology has not been as widely implemented as anticipated and in many devices tactile output is limited to the provision of simple alerts. The question arises as to whether this relatively narrow domain of application reflects limitations in the technology itself or in the ease with which tactile signals can be developed and implemented in different devices. The focus of the research is on developing the tools and human performance models so that designers can optimize the use of tactile technology in a variety of applications. This involves creating a library of vibrotactile stimuli that can be used to present a variety of tactile effects, and measuring the characteristics of these tactile signals when they are presented in wearable and hand-held devices.

Vibrotactile technology has not been as widely implemented as anticipated and in many devices tactile output is limited to the provision of simple notifications and alerts. As wearable haptic and tactile technologies become more pervasive, it will be critical to understand how the needs of a diverse user community can be met by providing them with the tools to customize haptic and tactile signals. A graphical design tool is being developed that can be used with different actuators to display vibrotactile effects physically and to determine their associated sensory and emotional attributes. User studies are conducted to evaluate the graphical user interface and assess the efficacy of the content presented. As part of this process, users indicate their preferences and associations for the stimuli displayed so that these can be incorporated into the interface. More widespread implementation of tactile communication will require that the technology can support a broader range of users and different user functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past decade many consumer devices have incorporated vibrotactile technology in order to augment the avenues of communication available to the user and to offload the overworked visual and auditory sensory systems. As these devices have become more pervasive, it is critical to understand how the needs of a diverse user community can be met by providing them with the tools to customize the sources of tactile communication. The goals of the present research have been to understand how best to design tactile signals for various devices such as cell phones or smart watches and to determine the organizational principles that govern how people perceive tactile signals so that such cues can be adapted to the needs of the user. Vibrations delivered to the skin vary in terms of a number of characteristics such as frequency, intensity, waveform, duration and repetition rate, all of which can be used to create the ?words? or tactons of tactile communication systems.  In this research a library of vibrotactile signals was created by varying these properties and these signals were then presented to users whose skin was in contact with the vibrating motor. Different motors, including a novel actuator technology developed in the laboratory, were used in these studies and they were positioned at a number of locations on the hand and arm.  Users judged how similar the various signals were and from these data the underlying dimensions used to perceive such vibrotactile signals were extracted. One fundamental perceptual dimension that emerged in this work was the role of texture, as defined in terms of a continuum that goes from rough to smooth, in vibrotactile perception. It was also determined that vibrotactile signals that vary along this continuum can be mapped onto real textures whose physical roughness varies. Such results provide support for the development of wearable tactile displays that relocate tactile cues away from the site of interaction in the environment, for example by presenting information normally experienced on the fingertips on the wrist, which frees the hands for other activities. The particular dimensions of vibration selected to represent different aspects of communication such as a cue regarding navigation, or an alert about an upcoming appointment were found to be context and user dependent.  Communication systems that use the skin can function as sensory substitution systems for individuals with impairments in other sensory modalities such as vision and audition. Touch-based interfaces have an impact on the avenues of communication available to visually-impaired individuals. In a variety of settings from classroom instruction to the pursuit of leisure activities a channel of communication like touch has the potential to enhance the capacity of the visually impaired individual to engage in the activity. For those with hearing impairments, tactile-auditory substitution aids are important for translating environmental sounds, such as a baby's crying or a siren, into time-varying patterns of vibration on the skin that can be readily identified and responded to. The present research provides a framework for designing these tactile signals in an optimal manner for a specific user.
